docs.lead_paragraph: The woman who backed out of her adoption of a 7-year-old Russian boy by putting him on a plane to Moscow by himself has lost her bid to keep from paying $150,000 in child support.

headline.main: Tennessee: Ex-Adoptive Mother Must Pay Support
headline.print_headline: Tennessee: Ex-Adoptive Mother Must Pay Support

docs.abstract: Torry Hansen, the woman who backed out of her adoption of a 7-year-old Russian boy by putting him on a plane to Moscow by himself, loses her bid to keep from paying $150,000 in child support.
docs.snippet: The woman who backed out of her adoption of a 7-year-old Russian boy by putting him on a plane to Moscow by himself has lost her bid to keep from paying $150,000 in child support.

docs.lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. - Brendan Hansen was in the middle of an interview at a pre-Olympics swimming camp Thursday when a scene a few yards away caught his eye. His 17-year-old teammate, Missy Franklin, spotted her father, Dick, who was visiting from Colorado, and ran into his embrace. Watching them hug, Hansen said, ''That's awesome.'' Hansen's wife, Martha, is expecting the couple's first child later this year. It thrills Hansen to know that no matter how he fares in London, he can count on 2012 being a watershed year.

headline.main: After Olympics End, Life As a Father Will Begin

docs.abstract: United States Olympic team swimmer Brendan Hansen is preparing for life as a first-time father after the London Games. (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Arizona’s law, which is to take effect Aug. 2, sets the earliest restriction on abortion of any of the eight other states that have similar laws.

headline.main: Lawsuit Tries to Block New Arizona Abortion Law
headline.print_headline: Lawsuit Tries to Block New Arizona Abortion Law

docs.abstract: Group of doctors and women's rights advocates challenge Arizona's new abortion limits in a federal lawsuit, claiming that they violate the Constitution and pose a threat to women’s health; law, set to take effect in August, prohibits abortions once 20 weeks have passed since a woman’s last menstrual period, weeks earlier than the threshold set by the Supreme Court.
docs.snippet: Arizona’s law, which is to take effect Aug. 2, sets the earliest restriction on abortion of any of the eight other states that have similar laws.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of doctors and women's rights advocates challenged Arizona's new abortion limits in a federal lawsuit on Thursday, claiming that they violate the Constitution and pose a threat to women's health. The law, set to take effect on Aug. 2, prohibits abortions once 20 weeks have passed since a woman's last missed period, which is about 18 weeks after fertilization. This is the earliest deadline set by any state and is weeks earlier than the threshold set by the Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the height of the crack era, teachers pitched education as the border between those who would prosper and those who would be fed to the great hydra of prison, teenage pregnancy and murder.

headline.seo: School as Wonder, or Way Out
headline.main: School as Wonder, or Way Out
headline.print_headline: School as Wonder, or Way Out

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Ta-Nehisi Coates reflects on his middling triumphs and spectacular failures as a schoolboy during the height of the crack era, contrasting his experience with that of his 11-year-old son in a progressive private school; observes that education remains the dividing line for black children between a life of prosperity or one of despair.
docs.snippet: At the height of the crack era, teachers pitched education as the border between those who would prosper and those who would be fed to the great hydra of prison, teenage pregnancy and murder.

docs.lead_paragraph: Neymar, a target of European teams since he was 14, has stayed home and become the face (and future) of his sport’s South American mecca.

headline.seo: Neymar, Soccer Prodigy, Is at Home in Brazil
headline.main: A Soccer Prodigy, at Home in Brazil
headline.print_headline: A Soccer Prodigy, At Home in Brazil

docs.abstract: Profile of Brazilian soccer prodigy Neymar, who, at 20 years old, is already the highest-paid and most admired soccer player in Brazil; he has opted to stay in his home country rather than building his career in a high-profile European league, as many other South American players have, and will play for Brazil at the London Olympic Games.
docs.snippet: Neymar, a target of European teams since he was 14, has stayed home and become the face (and future) of his sport’s South American mecca.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study published in The Lancet, a British science journal, suggests the maternal mortality rate could drop by a full third if all needs for family planning were met.

headline.seo: Meeting Contraception Needs Could Sink Maternal Death Rate
headline.main: Study Says Meeting Contraception Needs Could Cut Maternal Deaths by a Third
headline.print_headline: Study Says Meeting Contraception Needs Could Cut Maternal Death Rate by a Third

docs.abstract: Study by researchers at Johns Hopkins University and published in The Lancet shows that fulfilling unmet contraception demand by women in developing countries could reduce global maternal mortality by nearly a third, a potentially great improvement for one of the world’s most vulnerable populations; study comes ahead of a major family planning conference in London organized by the British government and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
docs.snippet: A study published in The Lancet, a British science journal, suggests the maternal mortality rate could drop by a full third if all needs for family planning were met.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE FACTS Obesity in pregnancy is a growing problem. Nationwide, about one in five expectant mothers is obese, and up to 40 percent of women gain more weight than recommended during pregnancy.

headline.main: Really? The Claim: Losing Weight Is Unsafe For Pregnant Women.

docs.abstract: Research has found that losing weight through diet and exercise can lower the risk of complications in pregnancy for overweight women. (M)
docs.snippet: THE FACTS     Obesity in pregnancy is a growing problem. Nationwide, about one in five expectant mothers is obese, and up to 40 percent of women gain more weight than recommended during pregnancy.
